column1: ecstasymodels 159848388117 "2017-04-22 03:03:55 GMT" http://ecstasymodel.com/post/159848388117/53-painful-horrible-hair-experiences-that-are-way "black-to-the-bones:  1. Waking up to the horror of your headscarf having slipped off in the middle of the night. 2. Trying to sleep with a fresh head of braids. 3. Or trying to tie your hair up within the first week of getting your braids done and wincing in agony. 4. Feeling a strange amount of anxiety every time you have to book a hair appointment
column2: even though you‚Äôve been booking hair appointments for several years. 5. Relentlessly scratching your scalp all week and then realising your mistake as soon as you get your hair relaxed. 6. Going to the toilet half way through getting your extensions done and finding hair in the most random crevices of your body. 7. Being given the painstaking task of having to pass your stylist the hair. 8. Being convinced to get a trim you definitely don‚Äôt want. 9. And then having your trust betrayed when your stylist takes three inches off and gives you a CUT instead. 10. Never being quite sure if the prices in your salon are set or entirely made up every time. 11. Being forced to cancel a plan because your stylist can only do your hair on Saturday at 11am. 12. Fake scratching the back of your hair to check the kind of progress you‚Äôre making. 13. And touching the little tuft of hair at the top of your head after six long hours and thinking you only have two braids left when you actually have 20. 14. Forgetting to bring enough food to the salon and having to mask the sound of your stomach rumbling. 15. Or eating all of your provisions in the first two hours and realising you‚Äôve been a fool. 16. Having your phone die halfway through your hair appointment. 17. When your stylist takes a break from your head every 15 minutes to have a conversation with their mate. 18. Or to chat on the phone. 19. Or to tend to their kids. 20. Or to do all three
column3: while eating a plate of food. 21. Being told to come to the salon at 1pm and seeing two people in front of you when you arrive. 22. Being told to come to the salon at 9am and they haven‚Äôt even opened the shop yet. 23. Feeling the heat catch the oil on your scalp as your hair‚Äôs being straightened. 24. Having your weave so tight that you can‚Äôt put your eyebrows down. 25. Breaking the hairdryer pick when your hair‚Äôs only half dry. 26. Snapping a comb in half while tending to the thickest part of your head. 27. Having your wig slip back a little too far and only realising several hours into the day when you check the mirror in the toilet. 28. Or wearing your wig on a particularly windy day and praying that it doesn‚Äôt get swept off your head. 29. Feeling the ache in your muscles and actually sweating while detangling your hair. 30. Procrastinating on washing your hair and then having to start the process of washing
column5: and detangling your hair at 10pm. 31. Feeling very dubious about your new stylist and asking them a trillion questions to make sure they don‚Äôt mess up your hair. 32. Or realising they‚Äôre not quite doing your hair the way you want
column6: but being too scared to say anything. 33. Having to do the duck and dive when someone tries to touch your hair. 34. Being asked if you cut your hair or ‚Äúgrew it‚Äù when you go into work with a new hairstyle. 35. Being asked if that‚Äôs your ‚Äúreal hair‚Äù and having to stop yourself from screaming ‚ÄúI BOUGHT IT
column7: SO HELL YEAH IT‚ÄôS MINE.‚Äù 36. Coming out of the salon when it‚Äôs raining and having to put a plastic bag over your head because you have no umbrella. 37. Hearing the words ‚Äúhold your ear‚Äù just before the hot comb narrowly misses burning it off. 38. Trying to scratch underneath your weave discreetly with a pencil or pen. 39. Or accidentally slapping your head so hard to itch your scalp that you almost knock yourself out in the process. 40. Watching shrinkage claim the length of your hair as soon as you wash it. 41. Being asked to have a sleepover on a whim and refusing because you don‚Äôt have your headscarf. 42. Sitting under the dryer for so long that you forget what life was like before you basically lived under it. 43. And when the dryer finally cuts off
column8: but your hairdresser tells you ‚Äúten more minutes‚Äù. 44. When you have to wash your hair in the kitchen sink and feel like your neck is gonna fall off at any minute. 45. Having extra long weave or braids and getting it caught in every zip
column9: door or piece of velcro you come into contact with. 46. Using more ingredients to wash your hair than you do when cooking yourself an actual meal. 47. Struggling to fit a hat over your afro and wondering why you bothered trying in the first place. 48. Falling asleep without your headscarf and waking up out of your sleep to put it on. 49. Watching someone who came to the salon after you leave before you. 50. Having to reject plans on wash day. 51. Having to reject plans on ‚Äútaking out my braids‚Äù day. 52. Having to reject plans when you‚Äôve already put your satin bonnet on. 53. Showing your stylist a picture of what you want and having them completely ignore you to do their own thing. That‚Äôs 53 reasons why i hate when white people are trying to copy our natural hairstyles or the hairstyles that have been invented by back people to cope with their hair. They‚Äôre doing this without thinking that they‚Äôre doing something wrong and pretend like they are so fresh and stylish giving no f**ks about cultural appropriation. If you still don‚Äôt think cultural appropriation is wrong re read 53 points above. Source " False text

column1: ecstasymodels 158281621883 "2017-03-11 21:00:23 GMT" http://ecstasymodel.com/post/158281621883/shooting-for-the-stars-at-age-22-tiera-guinn-is "black-to-the-bones:  Tiera Guinn is just 22 years old and she‚Äôs already working for NASA.  As a Rocket Structural Design and Analysis Engineer for the Space Launch System that aerospace company Boeing is building for NASA
column2: Guinn designs and analyzes parts of a rocket that she said will be one of the biggest and most powerful in history.  Have you already watched Hidden Figures? Tiera‚Äôs story closely resembles that of Mary Jackson who was played by Janelle Monae in the award-winning film.   Her mother noticed her daughter‚Äôs math skills and made her practice‚Ä¶¬†  at the supermarket.      ‚ÄúWhen [my mom and I] would go to the grocery store
column3: she would get me to clip coupons [and] put it in my coupon organizer
column4: ‚Äù Guinn told WBRC News. ‚ÄúBy the time we got to the register
column5: I‚Äôd have to calculate the exact total
column6: including tax. And I did that since I was six years old.‚Äù   Then one day she realised she can possibly design¬†   planes and she can¬†   be an aerospace engineer. And now she is a NASA engineer at the age of 22! ¬†And she will soon be graduating from MIT with a 5.0 GPA! What an incredible story! She follows her dreams and doesn‚Äôt let anyone to get in her way. A few decades ago she wouldn‚Äôt be even allowed to take a step into the building of NASA and now she‚Äôs an engineer there. Hidden Figures showed us how hard it was for Mary Jackson
column8: and Dorothy Vaughan ¬†and these women paved a way for us. She is a great role model for all the beautiful young black girls. Everything is possible! SOURCE VIDEO SOURCE " False text

ecstasymodels 152958084204 "2016-11-09 18:11:01 GMT" http://ecstasymodel.com/post/152958084204/nism-yprofile-nengi-willie-pepple "nismypro:  Nengi has always loved all things creative. She recalls being drawn to colours and scribbling from a very young age.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always been a lover of arts and crafts. Even when I was little
column4: everything. I just wanted to express myself creatively.‚Äù This stuck with her from her childhood in Port Harcourt
column5: and persisted through to her secondary school education in Adesoye College
column6: Offa ‚Äì a boarding school in Kwara State. Nengi might have been a long way from home
column7: but her natural instincts and talents never left her. Her current occupation as a fashion and lifestyle blogger is therefore no surprise
column8: but the journey to this point wasn‚Äôt so straightforward. When she was younger
column9: Nengi was never good with numbers and this plagued her with a nagging sense of self-doubt.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying everyone who is great at art isn‚Äôt good at science
column10: but that was definitely the case for me. I just didn‚Äôt understand Maths or Physics or anything like that. It was a real struggle for me. Eventually
column11: I just started to embrace it more and tried my best
column12: but I knew I didn‚Äôt understand or enjoy Maths and those other subjects.‚Äù Some would argue that Nengi‚Äôs experience is not unique within the Nigerian educational system. Many experience an unspoken bias towards the sciences
column13: which comes with a hefty dose of pressure. The perception that art subjects offer an easy alternative to more technical subjects causes a good number of creative students to neglect their natural gifts in favour of more respected fields of study. Admittedly
column14: this bias is likely to come from a place of concern ‚Äì science subjects often lend themselves more readily to specific professions than creative disciplines. Study medicine and become a doctor. Study engineering and your path is clear. Study fashion design and textiles and become‚Ä¶ A tailor
column15: perhaps? Even with a great support system
column16: a decision that goes against the grain of favoured traditional subjects could be a difficult one to come to terms with.  Ultimately
column17: Nengi put these worries aside and followed her instincts. Following a move to the UK
column18: she opted to study Textiles and Photography at GCSE level - two subjects which would become integral aspects of her future career. ‚ÄúThat was my first taste of what fashion was ‚Äì sewing
column19: putting together garments. Even in uni
column20: some of the stuff I did wasn‚Äôt as complex as what I did back then. I didn‚Äôt even know I was going to end up using Photography.‚Äù  Nengi hasn‚Äôt looked back since. She continued her study of Textile Design at A Level
column21: and went on to pursue a BA in the same subject at Leeds University. It was an incredibly robust degree
column24: knitwear and print in the first year of study
column25: before students were encouraged to specialise in one skill by their second year. In addition to the hands-on nature of the course
column26: it was also academically rigorous.  ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt just ‚ÄòCreate
column30: make!‚Äô. It was also ‚Äòlearn and write‚Äô.‚Äù ¬† As a result
column31: Nengi received thorough training in the practical techniques involved in garment production
column32: as well as sound instruction regarding the fashion industry and the various business models on offer within it. Her studies at Leeds culminated in a dissertation exploring the emergence and impact of sweat shops. Nengi submitted her final paper and graduated in 2014.¬†She then faced the same question many graduates have to answer: ‚ÄúWhat do I do now?‚Äù Being the hard worker that she is
column33: her response to this question was to hit the ground running. Straight after graudation
column34: ¬†Nengi completed a two month internship at Moschino
column35: another one at Diane von Furstenberg and also gained some work experience at Paul Smith. Working for these household names has furnished her with invaluable experience. ¬† ‚ÄúYou get to see the back-end of things. I went to the Moschino fashion show for menswear. That was really helpful for me. I [also] really look up to [Diane] as a woman in fashion. She‚Äôs come a long way and has done a lot for herself.‚Äù This experience only served to bolster Nengi‚Äôs on-going project. In 2012
column36: she had started a blog to document her personal style and had been running it alongside full-time study. She admits that she never took blogging seriously to begin with.  ‚ÄúIn my mind
column37: all I could do was get a job. I never thought I could do it for a living.‚Äù Yet
column39: her love for blogging only waxed stronger. However
column40: with graduation comes that all-important foray into adult life. That life came with responsibilities and the blog was not sufficient to cater to these
column41: so Nengi got a job.  ‚ÄúI got a full-time job at Selfridges. I was a Sales Associate in the Luxury handbags department.‚Äù  As is the case with anyone who has already discovered their passion
column42: no alternative could fully compare. ¬†Nengi was never truly fulfilled being a Sales Associate. She was experiencing a dilemma many talented young people face: continue a steady 9-5 or pursue your dream? Nengi found a solution in between
column43: and now splits her time between a part-time sales role and her duties as the creative director of her blog. Though she hopes to transition towards the latter outright
column44: she doesn‚Äôt regret a minute of her sales role.  ‚ÄúI can definitely say I learned a lot of customer service skills
column46: so I went down to part-time and my blog has definitely grown since.‚Äù  That blog is Runway Ribbons ‚Äì a thriving lifestyle
column47: fashion and beauty website with a burgeoning social media presence to boot. Nengi has almost 5
column48: 000 followers on Instagram ‚Äì an eager audience for her stylish outfit posts
column49: travelogues and musings. Her unique selling point is achieving high fashion looks with high street brands. Settling into this niche came with quite a few growing pains. The fashion industry is often seen as synonymous with pressure to follow expensive trends and subscribe to narrow beauty standards. At first
column50: Nengi was not immune to any of this.  ‚ÄúI was in this industry where everyone had all these amazing things and I just couldn‚Äôt afford it. I really wondered how I could take myself to the next level if I didn‚Äôt have the right bag or the right shoes.‚Äù It took some frank words from her mother to counter these negative feelings.  ‚ÄúMy mum said
column51: ‚ÄòIf you have all those things now
column52: what will be there to aspire to?‚Äô.‚Äù  Since then
column53: Nengi has decided to march to the beat of her own drum. She is a firm believer that success means different things to different people
column54: and one‚Äôs focus should remain centred on being one‚Äôs best self ‚Äì and not competing with others. One of her favourite quotes is ‚ÄúComparison is the thief of joy‚Äù ‚Äì a mantra she lives her life by. Still
column56: and she still has days when she wonders if she should have taken a more traditional path.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve had those moments when you rethink it and wonder if this is going to go anywhere.‚Äù This is where a strong support system comes in handy. Nengi credits friends and family with giving her the final push to take her career to the next level. From crafting unique and edgy outfits by putting high street pieces together
column57: Nengi‚Äôs next goal is to design and produce her own garments. ¬† ‚ÄúMy friends were always telling me
column58: ‚ÄòWhy aren‚Äôt you designing? Why aren‚Äôt you making your own clothes?‚Äô Even my mum told me
column60: why aren‚Äôt you using it?‚Äô.‚Äù These little sparks of encouragement were eventually ignited by a chance window shopping encounter.  ‚ÄúOne day
column61: I saw a top in Zara and it was ¬£30. I just knew it shouldn‚Äôt be so I went home and made the exact same top for like ¬£5 pounds and it took me 20 minutes! That definitely made me think.‚Äù That top became the first of a few
column62: one of which is pictured above
column63: and Nengi intends to keep designing and making her own items. Her passion for the craft is palpable ‚Äì she stresses the utmost importance of excellent finishing and takes pride in personally selecting the right fabrics for different designs. She sees her talent as a ready fix for a gap in the market ‚Äì many bloggers collaborate with clothing brands but rarely make or design their own clothes. With the skill to do so and an impressive platform to promote her products
column64: Nengi might just be on her way to becoming a household name. Her plans for the future are much more modest.  ‚ÄúI wish I could have a job that would allow me to travel the world. I‚Äôd be the owner and designer of my own company. I would like a small team; it doesn‚Äôt have to be too big. I just want my clothes to be out there and making a mark.‚Äù  We‚Äôll be watching this budding talent as she flourishes on the fashion scene. In the meantime
column65: keep up-to-date with her on her blog and social media platforms. " False text

column1: ecstasymodels 149856882711 "2016-09-02 22:49:55 GMT" http://ecstasymodel.com/post/149856882711/how-do-women-stay-stylish-while-working-full-time "ecstasymodels: While you may think that the effortlessly chic woman in your office is superhuman
column2: she‚Äôs just well prepared. You don‚Äôt see her hobbling around in broken heels or rushing to remove a stain from her blouse because she‚Äôs ready for such obstacles.Primp and PrepPlanning your outfit the night before is crucial to looking great the next morning. You may think you know exactly what you want to wear the next day
column3: only to find that the one piece you really wanted is still in last week‚Äôs laundry. Pulling out your clothes the night before ensures that you have a complete outfit and eliminates the morning panic to find a replacement.Even though your outfit is already prepared
column4: you still need to give yourself plenty of time to get ready in the morning. You never know when a shirt might rip or a heel may break! Take the extra time to fix your hair
column6: and select your jewelry.The right undergarments are often the hallmark of a well dressed woman. Choosing the silhouette that best suits your outfit helps you avoid awkward wrinkles
column8: and lines. They‚Äôll also provide appropriate support and coverage for any occasion.Compulsory Closet ComponentsMany women struggle to maintain stylish outfits due to a lack of certain wardrobe essentials. Slacks and stylish pants in black and charcoal
column9: in addition to a comfortable long sleeve woven shirt
column10: are often the base for a chic ensemble. Without well fitting basic pieces
column11: you won‚Äôt be able to create the look you desire.An important aspect of closet basics is color choice. A closet full of neutrals that are easily mixed and matched allow you the versatility to create an outfit out of anything you own. If you add just a few statement pieces to your wardrobe essentials
column13: office-ready clothes are always available.Accurate AccessoriesSometimes a simple outfit is elevated with colorful statement necklaces or elegant hand embroidered scarves. If you‚Äôre keeping your outfit neutral during work hours
column14: matching accessories enhances the effortless feel of your clothes and adds elegance and sophistication. One thing that will always elevate your outfit and mood is finding one piece that you can wear with everything. A diamond ring or estate earrings are enough to sensationalize your attire any day.Quick FixesThere are always days when everything seems to be going wrong: a pet got sick on your work uniform
column15: you tripped and fell on the grass
column16: or your clothes ripped on the way to work. Prepare for these emergencies with a few quick fixes. Stashing an extra outfit in the car or office is a lifesaver. You can also carry an emergency sewing kit and bleach pen in your purse for minor messes and holes.Stylish Working WomanFollowing these simple tips will turn you into the new office fashionista. Preparation
column18: and proper closet components are all you need to stay fashionable and polished. Don‚Äôt let the long work week keep you from looking droll‚Äîdress up and be a new you today!Author Bio:Andrew Hoffman is a freelance writer and journalist from Los Angeles
column20: who has written on behalf of a range of clients including the Livestrong Network and Demand Media.In addition to writing about a range of topics
column21: he enjoys surfing in Santa Monica and collecting classic
column22: first-edition novels. You can reach out to him here.  " False text
